questions.question: Why is rolling friction significantly less than sliding friction?

reasoning_steps.evidence: The animation starting at 1:13 shows a sphere rolling. The text 'ROLLING WITHOUT SLIPPING' appears on screen.
reasoning_steps.inference: the rolling object doesn't have the slipping friction.

reasoning_steps.evidence: An animation at 1:49 that labels the force at the point of contact as 'STATIC FRICTION'.
reasoning_steps.inference: The force is 'static friction'.

reasoning_steps.evidence: The narrator explains, 'At the theoretical point of contact between a perfect sphere and a surface, there is zero relative velocity between the two surfaces... The sphere experiences only static friction at this instantaneous point... This friction, however, requires much less force to overcome than kinetic friction would.'
reasoning_steps.inference: 'zero relative velocity' at the contact point and that static friction is much lower than kinetic (sliding) friction. The point of contact is momentarily at rest relative to the surface.

questions.answer: Because the contact point is momentarily stationary, experiencing only static friction.
options: A. Because the rolling object and surface undergo elastic deformation, forming a 'contact area'.
B. Because the spherical shape of the object minimizes air resistance to the greatest extent.
C. Because rolling motion continuously carries heat away from the contact point.
D. Because the contact point is momentarily stationary, experiencing only static friction.
